The study investigated the transfer hydrogenation of guaiacol, anisole, phenol, and positional isomers of dimethoxybenezene using 2-PrOH as the H-donor over Ni, Co, and Ni-Co catalysts. The catalysts, which contained 5 wt% metal, were prepared by the deposition-precipitation method. The results showed that the catalysts had developed a pore structure and fine metal particles. The Ni and Ni-Co catalysts demonstrated exceptional activity in the transfer hydrogenation of phenolic compounds with a substrate to metal molar ratio of 100 to 1. Furthermore, the addition of Co to Ni significantly impacted the selectivity of transfer hydrogenation promoting hydrodeoxygenation of anisole and guaiacol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Transfer hydrogenation Phenolic compounds 2-PrOH, Ni-Co catalyst Hydrodeoxygenation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Green chemistry principles recommend the use of renewable materials and selective catalysts to replace traditional sources and processes. Transfer hydrogenation (TH) is considered a greener alternative to conventional H2 hydrogenation because, in contrast to molecular hydrogen, H-donors such as alcohols are comparatively easy to obtain from inedible plant biomass [1,2]. In addition, H2 is known to be corrosive, explosive, and requires high-pressure equipment, which significantly limits its range of applications. At the same time, alcohols can exhibit H-donor activity under mild conditions [3–5]. In general, metal catalysts known to be active in conventional hydrogenation show promising results in TH [6–8]. It is important to note that in recent years the trend has shifted from the use of monometallic catalytic systems to multicomponent ones. The second metal can increase catalyst activity [9,10], stability [11,12], selectivity [13,14] or dispersion of an active component [15,16], which allows one to control catalyst properties by its content. For example, Kumar et al. demonstrated that supported catalysts containing Pd and Co are active in TH of carbonyl compounds, with bimetallic particles showing superior results. The authors mentioned a “synergetic effect” of two metals that defines the higher activity of PdCo nanoparticles compared to pure Pd and Co [10]. Recent studies have investigated the influence of Ni-Cu binary catalysts on biomass-like phenolic compounds [17,18]. It has been showed that the addition of Сu can facilitate the reduction transformations of oxygen-containing functional groups [19], while at the same time, it can have an opposite effect [20]. Synergism between Cu and Pd was also observed by the authors in TH of furfural [14]. This can be seen from the change in selectivity on a ratio of metals, in particular, it has been showed that 10Cu-3Pd/ZrO2 facilitates the formation of 2-methylfuran and 10Cu-3Pd/ZrO2 – 2-methyltetrahydrofuran. It can be seen that the mixed catalyst combines the advantages of two metals: Cu facilitates the reduction of furfural to furfuryl alcohol and Pd catalyzes the cleavage of the C-O bonds. Nickel based catalysts show lower activity in TH compared to noble metals, at the same time the high availability of these metals make them attractive [21–24]. Unfortunately, there are not many studies devoted to reductive transformations of organic compounds over Ni-Co catalysts in alcohols, however, some authors have demonstrated that Ni-Co catalysts are promising in TH of biomass-derived molecules, such as furfural [25], 5-hydroxymethylfurfural [26], 1-phenylethan-1-ol [27], and phenolic compounds [24,28]. The authors of these studies emphasize the synergetic effect of Ni and Co, which have limited activity in TH when used separately. For example, Wu et al. showed that the use of N1Co1 catalyst (Ni/Co molar ratio of 1:1) in furfural TH results in nearly 100 % conversion and the highest furfuryl alcohol yield, while Ni3Co1 and Ni1Co3 show lower efficiencies. At the same time, pure Co does not show high activity in TH compared to Ni [29,30] and it can decrease the activity of bimetallic systems, at the same time leading to the increase of the selectivity of TH [26]. Also, the addition of Co to Ni increases its stability in aggressive media, which allows the use of formic acid as hydrogen donor, in contrast to pure Ni-based catalysts, which do not show high activity with acids [31]. Binary Ni-Co catalysts showed excellent results in TH of N-containing molecules, such as 4-nitrotoluene [32], benzonitrile and other nitriles [33], under mild conditions. The authors mentioned a synergetic effect between two metals and a higher dispersion of bimetallic particles. Comparing this with the previous results [34,35], it can be concluded that the formation of Ni-Co metal particles hinders the poisoning effect of nitrogen atoms typical for single Ni. At the same time, it has been shown that conventional hydrogenation of phenolic compounds over Ni-Co catalysts may have some advantages over monometallic catalysts. For example, Blanco et al. showed that binary Ni-Co are more active than monometallic Ni and Co catalysts in the H2 hydrogenation of guaiacol at 300 °C [36]. Phenol and cyclohexanol were found to be the main products showing fast hydrodeoxygenation of the initial substrate. Also, the ratio of phenol to cyclohexanol increases with the growth of Co content, thus the addition of Co to Ni hinders the saturation of the aromatic ring due to higher dispersion of Ni atoms active in hydrogenation. Similar observations have been described by Zhou et al. showing excellent activity of Ni-Co catalysts in conventional hydrogenation of guaiacol [37]. The authors emphasized the importance of the oxide support, which facilitates hydrodeoxygenation through interaction with guaiacol and intermediates. In another study, it was shown that, in contrast to guaiacol, anisole does not lose oxygen atoms when converted to cyclohexanol and methoxycyclohexane over supported Ni-Co catalysts [38], and no hydrodeoxygenation products were observed in phenol conversions [39,40]. At the same time, Ni-Co catalysts demonstrated promising results in lignin depolymerization [24,41], which proves high activity of Ni-Co catalysts in CO bond cleavage. Based on the above reports, it can be concluded that conventional hydrogenation of phenolic compounds over Ni-Co catalysts may result in hydrodearomatization and partial hydrodeoxygenation. Thus, the data discussed above show that the use of binary metal catalysts allows the selectivity of conventional hydrogenation of phenolic compounds to be increased. We assume, that this feature of Ni-Co catalysts can be used in transfer hydrogenation of phenolics. This, combined with the low cost of the non-noble metals, will make it possible to create a competitive catalytic process. The objective of this study is to demonstrate the impact of Co addition to Ni/γ-Al2O3 on selectivity in the TH of guaiacol and other phenolic substances, including phenol, anisole, and isomeric dimethoxybenzenes (DMBs), the detailed kinetic analysis was applied. The catalysts were prepared by the deposition-precipitation method and characterized in detail. The effect of catalyst content, phenolic compound and temperature was investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and chemicals The following chemicals were commercially available and were used as received: Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99.2 %, Lenreactive), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (98.4 %, Lenreactive), aluminum hydroxide (Angarsk Catalysts and Organic Synthesis Plant JSC, trade mark A-64), urea (99.8 %, Lenreactive), ethanol (≥99.9 % Supelco), 2-propanol (≥99.8, EKOS-1), phenol (99.5 %, Vekton), anisole (99.7 %, Sigma-Aldrich), guaiacol (>98 %, Sigma-Aldrich), 1,2-dimethoxybenzene (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), 1,3-dimethoxybenzene (≥98 %, Sigma-Aldrich), 1,4-dimethoxybenzene (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), dodecane (≥99 %, Lenreactive). 2.2 Catalyst preparation and characterization Ni, Co and Ni-Co supported on γ-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by the deposition-precipitation method. The support was obtained from aluminum hydroxide by thermal treatment in air for 3 h at 700 °C. 33.4 mmol of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O or their equimolar mixture was dissolved in 640 mL of distilled water. Then, 30.88 g of γ-Al2O3 and 4.96 g of urea were added to the mixture consequently. Then, the resulting mixture was heated to 90 °C with stirring and kept at this temperature for 24 h. After this time, the mixture was cooled to ∼70 °C, the solid precipitate was filtered and washed with 1.5 L of hot (∼70 °C) distilled water. The air-dried samples were kept in an oven at 60 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 300 °C for 3 h. Before being used in the transfer hydrogenation, the oxidized catalysts obtained in the previous step were reduced in H2 flow at 550 °C (Ni/γ-Al2O3) and at 650 °C (Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 and Co/γ-Al2O3) for 45 min. XRD studies were performed using a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker) equipped with a LynxEye (1D) linear detector. The spectra were measured using the Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) with a step of 2Ө = 0.05° and an accumulation time of 3 s at each point. Prior to analysis the catalyst samples were reduced according to the standard procedure and then passivated in air. HRTEM investigation was performed using a ThemisZ electron microscope (Thermo Fisher Scientific) operated at 200 kV. For electron microscopy studies, the catalyst sample was deposited on perforated carbon substrates attached to aluminum grids using an ultrasonic disperser. Images were captured using a Ceta 16 CCD sensor (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Prior to analysis, the catalyst sample was carefully passivated by exposure to air. Inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP–AES, Optima instrument) was used to determine the elemental composition of metals in Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 and Co/γ-Al2O3. Prior to analysis, the catalyst was carefully passivated in air. The carbon, hydrogen and nitrogen contents were determined using a Vario EL Cube CHNOS analyzer (Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH). An ASAP-2400 automated volumetric adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics Instrument. Corp.) was used to measure the textural characteristics of the catalysts. Prior to analysis, the reduced samples were also passivated in air, dried under vacuum at room temperature, and then placed in a special cell under an inert argon atmosphere. After degassing at 100 °C and a residual pressure of 0.13 Pa for 7 h, adsorption isotherms were measured at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196 °C); the surface area (SBET) was determined by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method. Photoelectron spectra were recorded using a SPECS spectrometer (Al Kα irradiation, hν = 1486.6 eV, 200 W). The samples were supported on a double-sided conductive copper scotch tape. The binding energy scale was preliminarily calibrated using the positions of the peaks of the Au4f7/2 (BE = 84.0 eV) and Cu2p3/2 (BE = 932.67 eV) core levels. Prior to analysis all three samples Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 and Co/γ-Al2O3 were treated in the H2 steam (30 L/h) and then transferred in the glove box filled with Ar. CO pulse chemisorption was measured using a Chemosorb analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. Prior to experiment, 50 mg of each catalyst was placed in a U-shape quartz reactor and treated in an H2 steam (100 ml/min) while heating. Ni/γ-Al2O3 was heated to 550 °C, while Co-containing samples were heated to 650 °C. The reactor was held at the final temperature for 20 min and then purged with an inert gas (Ar), followed by cooling to room temperature. Pulses of CO were then added to the reactor (100 µL) until the amount of CO in the effluent stopped changing. The amount of chemisorbed CO was then estimated. Total acidity was measured by NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3 TPD). Prior to analysis, the samples were reduced in H2 stream according to the standard procedure described above. The catalysts were then carefully dried and passivated in air. The samples were fully saturated with NH3 (30 mL/min) in a quartz tube for 30 min and then purged with He (90 mL/min) for 60 min at 94 °C. Ammonia desorption was performed at a constant heating rate of 600 °C in a He flow of 60 mL/min. Gas mixtures were analyzed using an RGA100 mass-spectrometer (Stanford Research System). 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic experiments were performed in a 285-mL batch reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a sampler. The reactor was charged with 110 mL of EtOH or 2-PrOH, 9.3 mmol (0.87–1.28 g) of phenolic compound, and 0.10 g of dodecane, which was used as an internal standard. To the obtained mixture, the previously reduced catalysts were added: 0.63 g in experiments at 150 °C and 0.11 g at higher temperatures. The loaded reactor was purged with argon under intensive stirring and then heated to the target temperature of 150 °C, 250 °C and 275 °C for 15, 30, and 35 min, respectively. When the target temperature was reached (0 min) the mixture was sampled and then every 30 min. The qualitative and quantitative composition of the collected samples were analyzed using a Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 SE equipped with a 30 m quartz DM-35 column (bonded and cross-linked 35 % diphenyl/65 % dimethyl polysiloxane, ID 0.25 mm, df 0.25 μm). The products were identified by peak retention time and mass spectrum, which were compared with the corresponding data for pure compounds or with the NIST and Wiley electronic mass spectral libraries. The conversion of the initial substrates (Eq. (1)) and the yield of the products (Eq. (2)) were evaluated using the internal standard method with dodecane as the internal standard. (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( m o l . % ) = ( 1 − n ( p h e n o l i c c o m p o u n d ) i n n ( p h e n o l i c c o m p o u n d ) f i n ) × 100 % (2) Y i e l d ( m o l . % ) = n ( p r o d u c t ) n ( p h e n o l i c c o m p o u n d ) i n × 100 % where n(phenolic compound)in and n(phenolic compound)fin - amounts of phenolic compound in initial and final reaction mixtures, n(product) – amount of products formed during transfer hydrogenation. 2.4 Kinetic analysis The concentrations of the initial substrates and the intermediate and final products were described by a quasi-first order kinetic model with respect to the initial substrates and products. The reaction rate constants were determined by the least squares method using the analytical solution obtained. The following function was minimized: (3) F ( k → ) = ∑ i , j ( c i j e x p − c i c a l c ( t j , k → ) ) 2 where k → is a vector of reaction rate constants, k → = (k i); j is the serial number of an experimental point, tj is the time of the jth point, c ij exp is the experimental molar fraction of the ith component at time tj , c i calc ( t j , k → ) is the calculated molar fraction of the ith component at time tj . The values of c i calc ( t j , k → ) concentrations were calculated using the Runge-Kutta method [42,43]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization In the first stage of the work, the freshly prepared catalysts were characterized. The ICP-AES data are presented in Table 1 . The metal content calculated from the synthesis procedure should have reached 5 mass.% that is close enough to that obtained by ICP-AES data. The insignificant decrease may be due to incomplete precipitation of Ni2+ and Co2+ ions from the liquid during the catalyst preparation process. As seen, all the catalysts as well as the support possess similar textural characteristics, including BET surface area (SBET), pore volume (Vpore), and mean pore size (Dpore). At the same time, the chemical adsorption of CO demonstrated that the Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst adsorbs the largest amount of gas corresponding to 8.8 m2/g of metal on the catalyst surface (Table 1). It indicates a higher dispersion of the bimetallic Ni-Co catalyst compared to the monometallic samples, which correlates with known literature data [44,45]. The obtained results indicate a high dispersion of the synthesized catalysts, which is expected based on the properties of the initial support. XRD data obtained for calcined and reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. S10. As can be seen, only peaks related to the support are presented, which indirectly confirms high dispersion of metal particles. To clarify the structure and morphology of the synthesized catalysts, they were examined by HRTEM (Fig. 1 ). The obtained micrographs show small metal particles distributed throughout the support. Fig. 1 A1 and C1 show that the metal nanoparticles can form chains, which are typical for the catalysts prepared according to the deposition-precipitation method [8,46]. The distribution of elements obtained by EDX mapping is shown in Fig. 1 A3–C3. It can be seen that the small particles of Ni and Co are formed on γ-Al2O3 support. In the case of Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3, the metal particles are composed of both Ni and Co. The HRTEM data confirm the formation of Ni-Co mixed nanoparticles. XPS analyses were performed to study the surface microstructure of bimetallic supported nanoparticles. It was shown that the Ni2p peak related to metallic Ni has the typical binding energy value (852.6 ± 0.1 eV), which was observed for the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, at the same time, the peak shifts to 853.0 ± 0.1 eV when the Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 was analyzed (Fig. 2 ). This indicates the interaction between Ni and Co particles in the bimetallic catalyst, which is in agreement with the HRTEM data. The XPS analysis revealed a ratio of Ni to Co in the Ni-Co/Al2O3 catalyst of 0.65, which is consistent with previously published literature data [47] and indicates a surface enrichment with Co atoms. Thus, it can be concluded that the catalysts synthesized by the deposition-precipitation method have the developed pore structure and fine metal particles. Qualitative and quantitative analysis of acid centers on the catalyst surface was conducted via NH3 TPD (Fig. S9). The obtained data demonstrate comparable properties of the initial support, Ni/Al2O3 and Ni-Co/Al2O3. However, the addition of Co to the support significantly increases the number of weak, medium and strong acid centers. The Co/Al2O3 does not almost demonstrate activity in transfer hydrogenation under the conditions used (see below). Consequently, it can be concluded that the change in the number and strength of acid centers does not significantly influence the catalyst's activity and selectivity. 3.2 Transfer hydrogenation of phenolic compounds 3.2.1 Anisole The synthesized catalysts were used in TH of phenolic compounds such as anisole and positional isomers of dimethoxybenzene. These molecules represent products of lignin depolymerization [48,49], and were used as model substrates. It is important to note that the selected compounds have an aromatic ring and alkylated OH-groups, which is consistent with the qualitative content of lignin depolymerization products. At the same time, phenol and guaiacol contain non-alkylated OH-groups present in lignin [50], which should significantly accelerate TH according to literature data [9]. Two alcohols (2-PrOH and EtOH) were tested as solvents and hydrogen donors. EtOH showed no activity in TH, that corroborates known literature data [51,52]. Therefore, only the results obtained for 2-PrOH are discussed below. The study of anisole transformation over Ni/γ-Al2O3 in 2-PrOH showed a comparatively high conversion of the initial substrate of more than 98 % (here and further mole percentages are used) even after 2 h at 250 °C (Fig. S1). Methoxycyclohexane was found to be the main product reaching 75 % in the final reaction mixture, with two other important products being cyclohexanol (12 %) and cyclohexane (13 %). To demonstrate the effect of temperature, it was increased to 275 °C, because at higher values alcohol dehydration becomes too extensive. In this case, the conversion of anisole reached 99 % after 1 h, while the cyclohexane content in the final reaction mixture decreased to 6 %. It is interesting to note that lowering of the reaction temperature to 150 °C favors the selectivity to cyclohexane, which reaches 21 %, whereas at 250 °C this value is only 13 % with a similar conversion. Before discussing the obtained results in terms of rate constants, the kinetic model of anisole transformations was built. Based on the changes in conversion and product content, we assume that anisole is transformed in 3 main ways, as shown in Fig. 3 . For the experiment over Ni/γ-Al2O3 at 275 °C, no benzene was found as an intermediate product, indicating that the conversion of benzene to cyclohexane should be considered as a very fast reaction with a large rate constant. All reactions, except the anisole to benzene transformation, involve saturation of the aromatic ring, which may be accompanied by cleavage of CH3-O or Carom-O bonds. All of the proceeding transformations were considered to be irreversible and pseudo-first order reactions due to the large excess of 2-PrOH. The calculated rate constants are presented in Table 2 , and it is clearly seen that the k1 constant, which describes the transformations of anisole into oxygen-free products decreases slightly with increasing temperature. In contrast, other rate constants corresponding to the formation of cyclohexanol and methoxycyclohexane increase almost twofold. Thus, it can be concluded that the saturation of aromatic rings under TH conditions is more sensitive to temperature change and consequently has a higher activation energy. This is expected to lead to a significant decrease in the anisole conversion at 150 °C, which reaches 76 % after 5 h at the target temperature (Fig. S1), since the main contribution to the conversion is the hydrogenation of the benzene ring, which has low rate at low temperature. In contrast to the Ni-based monometallic catalyst, Co/γ-Al2O3 showed no activity in TH of anisole. It is known that monometallic Co often shows significantly lower activity than Ni in TH with alcohols used as H-donors [30,53], so the data obtained in this study are in agreement with literature reports. In terms of anisole conversion, the bimetallic Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showed a moderate result compared to the monometallic catalysts, since 63 % of anisole was converted to into products after 3 h at 250 °C (Fig. S2). The addition of Co to Ni has a limited effect on the quantitative composition of the products, in particular, the selectivity towards cyclohexane reaches the same 18 %. However, Co improves the CH3 O bond cleavage resulting in a higher selectivity to cyclohexanol found to be 24 % against 12 % obtained for Ni/γ-Al2O3. The modeling of the kinetic data indicates that all the rate constants calculated for Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 are significantly lower compared to those of the monometallic catalyst. At the same time, the difference between the k3 constants describing the formation of cyclohexanol for both catalysts is relatively smaller than between the k1, k2 and k4 constants (Table 2), which explains the higher selectivity to cyclohexanol over the bimetallic catalyst. The increase of the reaction temperature up to 275 °C results in a higher anisole conversion, which reaches 98 % after 3 h when used together with Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3. This is reflected in the rate constants, which became significantly higher, for example, the k1 constant increases from 0.076 ± 0.004 min−1 to 0.60 ± 0.01 min−1 (Table 2), it is important to note that the latter value is higher than for the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Also, the significant difference between Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 is observed under the milder conditions at 150 °C, since the conversion of anisole does not exceed 6 % after 3 h when the Ni-Co catalyst is used. Based on the above data, it can be concluded that the use of Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 has a negative effect on the aromatic ring saturation of anisole resulting in lower rate constants and conversion, and also decreased selectivity to methoxycyclohexane compared to Ni/γ-Al2O3, at the same time, Co facilitates hydrodeoxygenation, especially at higher temperatures. 3.2.2 Dimethoxybenzenes (DMBs) The conversion of dimethoxybenzene positional isomers, namely 1,2-dimethoxybenzene (1,2-DMB), 1,3-dimethoxybenzene (1,3-DMB) and 1,4-dimethoxybenzene (1,4-DMB) over both Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 was lower compared to anisole. However, all isomers showed similar results in terms of conversion, in particular, 92 %, 98 %, and 99 % of 1,2-DMB, 1,3-DMB and 1,4-DMB, respectively, were converted into products over Ni/γ-Al2O3 at 250 °C. Similar tendencies are maintained in the experiments performed over Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3, however, the addition of Co negatively affects the conversion of the initial substrates (Figs. S3–S5). Hydrodeoxygenation, hydrodearomatization and O-CH3 bond cleavage are typical for all dimethoxybenzenes as well as for anisole. Based on the experimental data, a scheme of five main routes of dimethoxybenzenes transformation was proposed (Fig. 4 ). It should be mentioned that the formation of intermediate products is also possible, for example, the small amounts of anisole were observed in some reaction mixtures. Moreover, the experiments with guaiacol (see below) show that 2-methoxycyclohexanol can be converted into cyclohexanol. We also assume that different transformation schemes can be realized for different DMBs, therefore in order to avoid mistakes in definition of transformation schemes and the comparison of kinetic constants, only final products were considered in the kinetic scheme. Using the proposed transformation scheme, the kinetic constants were calculated (Table 3 ). It is clearly seen that 1,3-DMB has the lowest k1 constant compared to other isomers when used over Ni/γ-Al2O3, which is reflected in the low selectivity to cyclohexane. At the same time, 1,3-DMB shows the fastest conversion to the products of partial hydrodeoxygenation – methoxycyclohexane (k2) and cyclohexanol (k3), whose rate constant reaches 0.426±0.003 × 10−2 min−1 and 1.343±0.004 × 10−2 min−1, respectively. The interesting detail is that no 3-methoxycyclohexanol was observed in the experiment with 1,3-DMB, so no the O-CH3 bond cleavage occurs when the molecule retains two oxygen atoms. In contrast to 1,3-DMB, the 1,2- and 1,4-substituted isomers have significantly higher k5 constants, describing a direct hydrodearomatization of the initial molecules, providing high selectivity to 1,2- (64 %) and 1,4-dimethoxycyclohexanes (46 %) observed in the experiments with the corresponding DMBs. The addition of Co to Ni mostly leads to a decrease in the rates of TH (Table 3), which is in good agreement with the lower conversion of all DMBs over Ni/γ-Al2O3 compared to other phenolics used in this work. In addition, Co significantly affects the selectivity of the transformations, primarily facilitating the hydrodearomatization of 1,2- and 1,4-substituted isomers. Comparing the selectivity of fully or partially deoxygenated products, such as anisole and its derivatives, at similar conversions, we can see (Table 4 ) that the presence of Co decreases the fraction of hydrodeoxygenated products from 29 % to 16 % for 1,2-DMB over Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3, respectively. For 1,4-DMB this parameter also decreased from 43 % to 35 %, while in the case of 1,3-DMB, Co slightly facilitates the hydrodeoxygenation. Also, it is important to note that hydrodeoxygenation has the highest reaction rate for 1,3-DMB, which is in agreement with the calculated rate constants (Table 4) and our recent results [9]. The reasons explaining the differences in TH of DMBs can be attributed to the different geometry and electronic properties of the positional isomers of dimethoxybenzene. On the one hand, it is obvious that 1,2-DMB and 1,4-DMB, in contrast to the 1,3-substituted substrate, have the consistent donating effect of the substituents. On the other hand, the oxygen-containing functional groups participate in the adsorption of the molecules on the catalyst surface, which is in good agreement with the literature data [54,55], so we can assume that the positions of the substituents relative to each other play an important role in the adsorption and further transformations of DMBs. In particular, a higher rate of hydrodearomatization may indicate a more intense interaction of the aromatic ring with the catalyst surface, leading to a faster saturation of the C=C bonds, while hydrodeoxygenation, which is predominant for 1,3-DMB, indicates the crucial role of oxygen-containing functional groups in adsorption. 3.2.3 Guaiacol and phenol In contrast to anisole, phenol was completely converted into the only product – cyclohexanol -even after 2 h at 150 °C with Ni/γ-Al2O3, thus no products of phenol hydrodeoxygenation were found in the reaction mixture. It shows that phenol containing non-alkylated OH-group, has higher reactivity compared to anisole over Ni catalysts, which is in good accordance with the known literature data [55]. At the same time, no conversion of phenol was observed over Co/γ-Al2O3 at 150 °C, however, at 250 °C the conversion reaches 94 % after 3 h. Phenol is mostly converted to cyclohexanol, however, the content of cyclohexanol decreases from 100 % to 68 % increasing with reaction time (Fig. S6). In addition to cyclohexanol, reaction mixtures contained significant amounts of cyclohexene and isopropoxybenzene indicating an intensification of acid-catalyzed transformations such as alkylation and dehydration. Cyclohexene formation was not observed in the experiments with Ni-containing catalysts, because alkenes are known for their high reactivity in Ni-catalyzed TH [5,56], therefore they quickly transform into alkanes. Isopropoxybenzene shows stability over Co/γ-Al2O3, which is also typical for other O-alkylated substrates. This feature of the transformations catalyzed by Co/γ-Al2O3 reflects its low activity in hydrogenation processes. This is in agreement with the results obtained for O-alkylated compounds, such as anisole or DMBs, since Co/γ-Al2O3 shows no activity in their transformations under TH conditions. Guaiacol as well as phenol has a non-alkylated OH-group, which should significantly increase its conversion in TH catalyzed by the Ni-containing catalysts. Indeed, after 5 h at 150 °C over Ni/γ-Al2O3, 92 % of guaiacol was converted into products which were cyclohexanol (31 %) and 2-methoxycyclohexanol (59 %) (Fig. S7). The content of cyclohexanol increased with increasing temperature, reaching 37 % and 42 % at 250 °C and 275 °C, respectively, when full or almost full conversion was achieved. Thus, hydrodeoxygenation has a greater effect on guaiacol conversions at higher temperatures. In addition to the products mentioned, small amounts of 1,2-cyclohexanediol, cyclohexane and isopropoxycyclohexane were also detected. The use of the bimetallic Ni-Co catalyst results in fast guaiacol conversion, reaching 100 % after 1 h at both 250 °C and 275 °C. As for Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3, cyclohexanol and 2-methoxycyclohexanol were found to be the main products, while the selectivity to cyclohexanol reached 67 % and 71 % at 250 °C and 275 °C, respectively (Fig. S8). Thus, compared to the monometallic catalyst, the binary Ni-Co system facilitates the conversion of guaiacol in cyclohexanol, which is in good agreement with the results of conventional hydrogenation [37]. The minor products of the guaiacol transformations were the same for both catalysts. To calculate the rate constants, the scheme of guaiacol transformations (Fig. 5 ) was assumed, which includes irreversible saturation of the aromatic ring that can be accompanied by cleavage of the C-OCH3 bond. It is interesting that the OH-group is mostly retained in the molecule, as has been showed for phenol. The formed products can participate in further comparatively slow reactions, e.g. 2-methoxycyclohexanol can be converted to cyclohexanol, whose OH-group can be alkylated with 2-PrOH. Analysis of the kinetic data for Ni/γ-Al2O3 shows that the k1 and k3 constants describing the formation of cyclohexanol and 2-methoxycyclohexanol from guaiacol (Table 5 ) are almost the same at both 250 °C and 275 °C. At the same time, the cleavage of the OCH3-group resulting in the formation of cyclohexanol from 2-methoxycyclohexanol becomes faster, leading to higher selectivity to cyclohexanol at higher temperatures. The conversion of guaiacol to cyclohexanol over Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 has significantly higher rate constants, which reach 5.42 ± 0.05 min−1 and 8.6 ± 0.2 min−1 at 250 °C and 275 °C, respectively, versus 2.18 ± 0.03 min−1 and 2.20 ± 0.06 min−1 obtained for Ni/γ-Al2O3. At the same time, the rate constant corresponding to the saturation of aromatic ring of guaiacol, which leads to the 2-methoxycyclohexanol proportion decrease when the bimetallic catalyst is used. Thus, it is clearly seen that the addition of Co to Ni results in slower saturation of the aromatic ring and improves the partial hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol. The data obtained in this study and in previous studies can be used to propose a mechanism for transfer hydrogenation over Ni/Al₂O₃ and Ni-Co/Al₂O₃ (Fig. 6 ). The addition of a second metal to nickel can have a different influence on the catalytic properties [57–59]. For instance, the effect of Co can be attributed to the destruction of Ni ensembles on the surface of metal particles, which impedes the saturation of aromatic rings. Furthermore, Co, which is a more oxyphilic compound [57], can facilitate the adsorption of oxygen-containing functional groups. Additionally, it can be facilitated by modifying the electronic structure of the active compound. It can be postulated that the promotion effect of Co in the hydrodeoxygenation of anisole and guaiacol is related to more effective adsorption of OH- and CH3O-groups, which results in faster deoxygenation. 4 Conclusions This work presents the comparative catalytic performance of Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3, and Co/γ-Al2O3 in the transfer hydrogenation of phenolic compounds, including phenol, guaiacol, anisole, 1,2-, 1,3-, and 1,4-dimethoxybenzene using 2-PrOH as a hydrogen donor. The results indicate that Co/γ-Al2O3 is inactive in the transfer hydrogenation of OH-free molecules. In contrast, the monometallic Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits excellent activity in reductive transformations of anisole, isomeric dimethoxybenzenes, phenol, and guaiacol. The addition of Co to Ni results in a decrease in the reaction constants compared to Ni/γ-Al2O3, due to the slowdown of the saturation of aromatic rings, which is a dominant process over the monometallic catalyst. However, this is not the case for guaiacol, which transforms faster over the bimetallic catalyst. The selectivity of the transfer hydrogenation is significantly affected by the presence of Co, particularly promoting hydrodeoxygenation of both anisole and guaiacol at 275 °C. In addition, the study performed has been demonstrated that the structure of phenolic compounds affects their conversion. Specifically, molecules containing non-alkylated OH-groups, such as phenol and guaiacol, exhibit higher activity in converting to products, which is consistent with existing literature. For instance, the conversion of phenol over Ni/γ-Al2O3 reaches 100 % after 2 h at 150 °C, whereas for anisole, the conversion rate was only 35 % under the same conditions. The isomeric dimethoxybenzenes exhibit comparable conversions, ranging from 57–67 % to 92–99 % over Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/γ-Al2O3, respectively. The reaction mixtures predominantly yield hydrodeoxygenation products with 1,3-dimethoxybenzene, while hydrodearomatization is more typical for 1,2- and 1,4-substituted isomers. coredata.dc:description: The study investigated the transfer hydrogenation of guaiacol, anisole, phenol, and positional isomers of dimethoxybenezene using 2-PrOH as the H-donor over Ni, Co, and Ni-Co catalysts. The catalysts, which contained 5 wt% metal, were prepared by the deposition-precipitation method. The results showed that the catalysts had developed a pore structure and fine metal particles. The Ni and Ni-Co catalysts demonstrated exceptional activity in the transfer hydrogenation of phenolic compounds with a substrate to metal molar ratio of 100 to 1. Furthermore, the addition of Co to Ni significantly impacted the selectivity of transfer hydrogenation promoting hydrodeoxygenation of anisole and guaiacol.
coredata.dc:title: Bimetallic Ni-Co catalyst for improving selectivity in transfer hydrogenation of phenolic compounds
